author: Jaspal Singh
title: 5 Best Instagram Growth Strategies for 2025
text:
Instagram has ceased to be a photo-sharing application, as it has become one of the most effective branding, e-commerce, and personal influence platforms in the world. The competition is stiffer than ever before in 2025 when it comes to attention.
To increase your following, the engagement, and to be featured on the Explore Page, you will not only require good content but strategy as well.
1. Maximize Saves, not merely Likes
Likes will remain, but in 2025, the new benchmark of a good engagement metric is a save. The algorithm of Instagram considers saves as a powerful signal that your post is useful and worth reminding more people about.
To save more:
- Share educational or inspiring (infographics, tutorials, quotes)
- Include carousels and mini-guides
- Add CTAs, such as “Save this later” to your captions
Need to get your save metrics going? Services like buy Instagram saves can help amplify your posts and signal value to the algorithm.
2. Take Advantage of Quality Story Impressions.
Stories are still a high-performing format, and posting behind-the-scenes content is not sufficient. In 2025, it becomes strategic – consistency, use of stickers, swipe-ups, polls, and impressions tracking.
Combining this with an impression boost via reputable services such as Poprey will enable you to achieve greater reach in your Stories, as well as a higher position in the Story ring. Greater impressions mean greater visibility which means more engagement.
3. Engagement Packages that are algorithm friendly should be used.
Instagram identifies patterns – and punishes those that look unnatural. Rather than haphazardly increasing a single metric, employ bundle engagement packages that include:
- Likes
- Comments
- Views
- Saves
- Impressions
Poprey provides such packages, and it assists you in creating a natural-looking engagement profile, which aligns with the way real users engage with the trending content.
With the imitation of these organic signals, your post will be much more likely to appear in Explore and Hashtag results – the places that will bring you the actual traffic and discovery.
4. Post More Reels -But With A Reason
Reels have maintained their dominance over the reach on Instagram, however, not every Reel is treated equally.
In 2025, winning Reels:
- Trending audio can be smartly used.
- Narrate or lesson in a flash
- Provide captions to silent audience
- Belong to a niche content plan (fitness tricks, beauty regimes, crypto guidance, and so on).
It is also possible to give a push to new Reels using the targeted views and impression strategies offered by Poprey so that they could get the initial traction – which is important to get picked up by the algorithm.
5. Make Followers Superfans
The last and most sustainable community is community building. Growth does not necessarily concern numbers only – it is about building a cult following of people who like and comment on everything you share.
Try this:
- Reply to all comments and DMs
- Ask users to tag friends and giveaways be hosted.
- Repost user-generated content to your Stories.
- Make special close friends Story content
The more users start to use it on a regular basis, the more saves, impressions, and shares your content will get automatically the same metrics that contribute to reach.
On Instagram in 2025, it is not about shallowness but rather saves, impressions, and story interactions are more important than mere likes. By using such tools as Poprey and such strategies as saving content, optimizing Reels, and growing engagement through bundles, creators and brands will be able to outsmart the algorithm.
Whether you’re an aspiring influencer or scaling your business, start using these five strategies today — and combine them with buy Instagram saves or impression boosters to supercharge your growth the smart, safe, and sustainable way.
FAQ
1. In 2025, will Instagram saves be more important than likes?
Yes. Whereas the number of likes continues to contribute to the engagement metric, saves have emerged as an important indicator to the Instagram algorithm in 2025. Saves mean people thought your content was worth bookmarking to come back to later and sends the platform a signal that your post is relevant in the long term. Because of this, they are more likely to reappear in feeds and Explore Pages as a saved post.
If you’re struggling to increase saves organically, services where you can buy Instagram saves — especially from trusted platforms like Poprey — can help kickstart engagement and push your content into algorithmic circulation.
2. Can I buy impressions or saves using services such as Poprey?
Definitely, with a trustful provider, such as Poprey, you are provided with algorithm-conscious, secure delivery. Poprey does not employ false bots and spam strategies. Rather, it emulates the actions of real users, providing impressions, likes, or saves over time and naturally so as not to raise any Instagram suspicions.
This strategy will help protect your account and boost the correct engagement cues. Services such as Poprey allow thousands of influencers and businesses to scale without breaking the policies of Instagram.
3. What is the number of Instagram saves or impressions I need to purchase to notice real results?
It depends on the company, there is no magic number, but as a rough guide:
- When working with a new account, it is better to begin with a small number: 100 500 saves or impressions.
- Influencers or businesses that are still growing can get a substantial boost by 1,0005,000 saves.
- In the case of viral campaigns, 10K+ impressions in Reels and Stories can promote reach fast.
Poprey packages are customizable and goal oriented. Saves are always better when they are accompanied by other indicators (likes, comments, impressions) to form a comprehensive growth strategy that the Instagram algorithm loves.
4. What is the point in purchasing Instagram impressions and saves or likes?
Purchasing impressions can increase visibility on its own, however, by layering impressions with other indicators of interest, such as likes, comments, or saves, you can duplicate a natural growth pattern. The algorithm used by Instagram is aligned to encourage coordinated patterns of engagement, e.g., a post earning impressions and getting likes and being saved.
Such multi-signal action causes the post to appear hot and frequently places it in Explore or in the top feed slots of followers. Poprey focuses on such engagement packs, which is why it is simpler to become bigger without appearing unnatural.

author: Chelsey Watts (FleishmanHillard)
title: It's official: AI has transcended hype
text:
It’s official: AI has transcended hype
From tech trend to essential tool—AI is reshaping industries and the entire communications landscape.
Last February, we published research analyzing how three technologies—AI, the Metaverse and NFTs—took different paths in public conversation. In their early months, all three rocketed out of the gate… but only AI had staying power.
One year later, our team re-ran the numbers and guess what? The AI hype train didn’t just keep going—it firewalled the throttle. Just look above at what happened to the right of the dashed line, which was the graph one year ago!
The latest data on Google Search trends shows AI interest has completely eclipsed other major tech buzzwords and the gap has only widened.
Why? Because AI isn’t just hype—it’s transforming industries in real-time. Unlike NFTs, which had their speculative boom-and-bust, or the Metaverse, which still struggles to find its mainstream purpose, AI is delivering tangible, world-changing results that transcend not only industry but the gap between B2B and B2C communications.
Consider:
- GenAI: Tools like ChatGPT, Midjourney and Claude are reinventing content creation—from writing to art to code.
- Enterprise Adoption: Businesses are integrating AI to automate workflows, boost productivity and make better decisions.
- AI in Daily Life: From customer service chatbots to AI-powered search, AI is fast on its way to becoming an everyday utility, not just a novelty.
The real question now isn’t whether AI interest will level off before the next time we run the numbers (because it won’t). It’s how much bigger can it get?
What This Means for Communicators
We can’t help but apply this AI momentum to the thing we do – help brands and organizations communicate, so here are a few trends we’re following closer to home:
- Transforming Storytelling: AI is enabling hyper-personalized content (both in creation and delivery) and data-driven messaging, allowing brands to connect with audiences in more meaningful ways.
- Shaping Media Strategies: AI-powered analytics are refining how communicators measure impact, predict trends and optimize outreach efforts.
- Enhancing Crisis Communications: With real-time monitoring and sentiment analysis, AI helps communicators anticipate and manage brand reputation more effectively.
- Redefining Audience Engagement: From AI-generated content to chatbots handling real-time interactions, AI is changing how brands interact with stakeholders.
For communication professionals navigating this AI-driven landscape, the data presents a clear directive: AI is no longer optional—it is essential. Here are three ways that communicators can stay ahead:
- Integrate AI Tools: Leverage AI-driven analytics, sentiment analysis and automation to enhance strategy and execution.
- Experiment with AI-Generated Content: Test AI-driven copywriting, video generation and personalization to refine messaging and engagement.
- Invent, then invent again: AI’s evolution is rapid. Communicators must remain agile, continuously learning and experimenting with new capabilities.
While other tech fads come and go, AI will continue to reshape how brands tell their stories, connect with audiences and measure success.
AI isn’t just a tool for efficiency—it’s a strategic imperative. Communicators who embrace AI today will be the ones shaping the conversations of tomorrow.
(Rita Herbstman and Maddie Blanz from our TRUE Global Intelligence practice contributed to this article, as did designer Josh Kirk.)

author: Canadian Press
title: Records for warmest December set or tied in Vancouver and other parts of B.C. - Pique Newsmagazine
text: VANCOUVER — Data from Environment Canada has confirmed what winter sport enthusiasts have known for a while — December was warm in British Columbia. Five communities in the province set or equalled temperature records for the month while the warm weather, combined with a lack of rain or snow, has done little to ease ongoing drought concerns. Meteorologist Brian Proctor said the mean temperature at Vancouver International Airport last month was 7 C, tying with 1939 as the city's warmest December on record since data started being collected in 1896. The mean temperature was 3.4 degrees higher than what is considered normal for the month. Proctor said Tuesday that warm weather records for December were also either set or tied in Victoria, Comox, Campbell River and Abbotsford. The month was also very dry, meaning there wasn't enough rain or snow to ease drought concerns in the province, he said. In the northeastern municipality of Chetwynd, for example, less than a millimetre of precipitation was recorded in December. The community usually sees about 19 millimetres. "In general terms, it hasn't been enough to alleviate the long-standing drought," Proctor said. "It's helped to sort of pull it back a little bit, but what we really do need, more than anything else, is we need snowpack. And we're not getting snowpack out of these kinds of systems at this point in time." The province's final drought update of the year, posted at the end of November, lists eight of B.C.'s 34 basins at the two highest levels of risk for adverse drought impacts. The northeast corner of B.C., which includes the Fort Nelson and Peace regions, remains at the highest level of drought where adverse impacts are almost certain. Proctor says the first full week of January is expected to get cooler with some snow possible at higher elevations This report by The Canadian Press was first published Jan. 2, 2024. The Canadian Press Note to readers: This is a corrected story. A previous version said December wasn't warm enough to break records in British Columbia. In fact, Environment Canada now says multiple communities either broke or tied heat records.

author: EFE
title: Una ONG denuncia la muerte de 14 personas en una zódiac al sur de Canarias
text:
Inmigración
Una ONG denuncia la muerte de 14 personas en una zódiac al sur de Canarias
La embarcación, en la que viajaban 58 personas, se ha desinflado a unos 55 kilómetros de la costa marroquí, según Caminando Fronteras, que pide rescatar a los supervivientes
EFE
Al menos catorce personas han muerto ahogadas en una zódiac cuyos ocupantes llevan pidiendo auxilio desde las 14.00 horas de este jueves desde un punto del Atlántico situado a unos 55 kilómetros de Cabo Bojador, en la costa marroquí del Sáhara Occidental, al sur de
[Canarias](/es/temas/islas-canarias-1848283), porque su barca se desinfla y se hunden.
Es la denuncia que realiza la activista Helena Maleno, fundadora de Caminando Fronteras, ONG que lleva toda la tarde de este jueves en contacto con los náufragos y que ha transmitido su posición a las autoridades españolas y marroquíes para que movilicen medios de rescate. Por la localización del incidente, ha asumido la emergencia Rabat.
Maleno ha facilitado a EFE una foto enviada por los supervivientes que todavía siguen a flote, una imagen nocturna y borrosa en la que se ve a entre seis y siete personas sentadas a horcajadas sobre un flotador de una neumática, doblado y medio deshinchado.
Y también un audio que le ha remitido una de las ocupantes de la patera. En él se escucha a una mujer decir en francés: "Estamos aquí, Helena. Soy una mujer embarazada de nueve meses, estoy en el flotador (de la zódiac). Todos los chicos del medio (de la embarcación) han desaparecido, la gente está desapareciendo, hasta ahora no hemos visto a la Marina".
"Toda la gente está desapareciendo. ¡Por favor ayúdennos, ayúdennos! ¡Estamos aquí, ayúdennos! Estamos sentados así en el flotador (se refiere a la imagen que adjunta con el audio). Es muy peligroso, el agua está entrando", se lamenta la mujer
Helena Maleno ha explicado a EFE que, según la información que han recabado sobre esa neumática, se trata de un grupo de 58 personas que salieron el miércoles desde la costa del Sahara hacia Canarias y que ahora se encuentran al suroeste de Cabo Bojador.
Entre ellos, añade, hay siete mujeres (incluyendo a la embarazada) y dos niños.
La portavoz de Caminando Fronteras denuncia que, hasta el momento, Marruecos no ha hecho llegar ayuda a los ocupantes de esa neumática, ni tampoco Salvamento Marítimo español ha intervenido.
Por eso, expresa su temor a que ocurra lo mismo que el 21 de junio, cuando varias personas murieron al hundirse una zódiac al sur de Gran Canaria después de pasar toda la noche esperando a que llegara una patrullera de Marruecos, porque la emergencia la había asumido el Centro de Coordinación de Salvamento de Rabat.
Y ello, a pesar de que un barco de rescate español había estado a solo una hora de distancia de navegación de ellos, socorriendo a otra patera, cuando ya se conocían sus coordenadas.
Ese suceso dio lugar una denuncia de la Fiscalía de Canarias por presunto delito de omisión del deber de socorro contra los responsables del operativo en España, denuncia que desde este verano instruye un Juzgado de Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, que ha declarado secretas las actuaciones.
Joao Cancelo desvela qué compañero en el Barça le ha impactado Estas han sido algunas de las mejores inocentadas del 28 de diciembre en el "Día de los Inocentes" Mika Faye cotiza al alza: Primer equipo, Girona... o un grande europeo Pilar Rubio pasa la Navidad junto a esta famosa persona mientras Sergio Ramos estaba con su familia CAMPEONES DE HONOR. Carme Valero: "Nos decían que no podíamos ganar nada por ser culonas y pechugonas" Vitor Roque llega con deberes ya hechos Douglas Luiz, el pivote preferido de Deco El 1x1 del posible once del Barça del futuro Críticas a Neymar en Brasil: "Eligió no ser un jugador de alto nivel" El Barça toca fondo en Málaga ante un Unicaja imperial

author: Glasgow Times
title: Brighton are no Premier League's nice guys – they're horrible to play against
text:
The Telegraph Brighton are no Premier League nice guys – they are horrible to play against Read full article Thom Gibbs 29 December 2023 at 0:11 am · 3-min read Captain Lewis Dunk helps to give Brighton an uncompromising edge - Reuters/John Silbey
From a distance, the patronising assumption is that Brighton and Hove Albion are one of the “nice” football clubs. Their feelgood comeback story, from when the record label Skint was a grimly apposite shirt sponsor; the cheerful gull on the emblem; the dozens of keen young boys poring over spreadsheets in an underground scouting bunker. What is not to like? Plenty, if you are unfortunate enough to be playing against them.
Tottenham were terrorised into nervy mistakes from scrambled thinking in the first half, punished every time they hesitated. Danny Welbeck closed down Ben Davies to win a corner, the Spurs defender punched the air in anger. Seeing his team so cowed with their passing, the otherwise impassive Ange Postecoglou span around in frustration as one too many balls was worked backwards.
The Spurs manager would prefer his team to be on the front foot forever, but Brighton gave them little opportunity for 80 minutes, playing with a physicality and speed Spurs could not match.
There were glimpses of vulnerability. Spurs targeted left-back Igor Julio with occasional success in the first half but Pervis Estupinan replaced him at the break, a weak link immediately tightened by a full-back who can casually slam in a third goal from 30 yards.
It is all led by Roberto De Zerbi, who looks like a complete nightmare to work for. Within minutes he was swearing at his colleagues on the bench as if they were the ones who failed to award a foul for a marginally too-strong Tottenham challenge. Any balls sent out of play but into his orbit were caught or controlled as if to make a point: standards. Even when it literally does not matter.
Roberto De Zerbi has the respect and ear of his players - Reuters/Dylan Martinez He clearly has the ear of his players and it does not hurt to have the fans helping to build a siege mentality. After one debatable decision against, with the manager’s recent broadsides at referees fresh in the mind, the home supporters chanted “De Zerbi’s right / the refs are s----”. No let up from assistant Andrea Maldera either, bad cop to De Zerbi’s worse cop, who seemed furious with sub Carlos Baleba for failing to return quickly enough from a touchline warm-up.
Story continues None of this would fly if the results were not forthcoming or, crucially, if it were not fun. It is an odd feature of Brighton’s galaxy-brained recruitment strategy that they rely on some players who are apparently past their peak. Danny Welbeck, with career seemingly in decline, looks utterly re-energised, James Milner is still playing at the ripe old age of 83, started off in the middle then drifted onto the left wing and hit a post at 2-0 with a long range screamer which would have brought the house down.
There is plenty of skill too, Brighton’s tenacity earning their flair players to deploy their talents when appropriate. The first goal came after Joao Pedro took a circuitous but high-speed route around a baffled Spurs defence. But mostly you notice Brighton’s grit.
Every corner is a threat, every high ball is contested with gusto, enormous centre backs Lewis Dunk and Jan Paul van Hecke used their physicality to the limit of the rules. Joao Pedro took a mild brush in the face from Richarlison as his invitation to roll around as if assaulted with an anvil. Usually this is behaviour which turns other clubs’ fans against you, but Brighton’s intensity does the opposite. Their clear fallibility at the back helps.
An untidy end to their game made the final minutes needlessly tense, with their occasionally frantic defending finally punished after a number of offside reprieves. Dunk looked too tired to challenge Ben Davies for Spurs’ second and a game which seemed settled stayed exciting to the end.
Here is something for the neutrals, steel and softness together. At both ends, Brighton are thrilling to watch when playing like this.
TRENDING 1. Experience: I’m a world champion pea thrower 2. The 10 greatest commentary moments in sports history 3. When is Dancing on Ice 2024 and who are the hosts? 4. At least 30 E.coli cases could be linked to recalled cheese, say health officials 5. Strictly Come Dancing star John Whaite pulls out of stage role due to illness

organizations.name: telegraph brighton are no premier league

author: 三立新聞網
title: 獨家／寵物殯葬亂象多！500克小白鼠火化被收5000元 飼主崩潰
text:
記者李育道／台北報導
▲一隻重量500g的寵物鼠火化竟被收費5000元，讓飼主很驚訝。（圖／讀者提供）
有鑑於近幾年來隨著少子化的影響，寵物逐漸被視為家庭的一員，每一年新登記的寵物比新生兒數量還要多，全台寵物數量超過279萬隻（有登記的數量），而心愛寵物離世後，飼主們都希望能好好送別，但目前無相關定價與法規，導致寵物殯葬業坐地喊價，有讀者向《三立新聞網》投書，一隻體重500公克的寵物鼠火化費用竟被收取5000元，讓飼主好驚訝，寵物去當天使已經很悲傷了，處理後事竟被收超乎預期的天價。對此，農業部動保局陳中興副司長允諾，會於六月底前，研擬定型化契約草案，保護消費者有公開透明的收費標準。
《殯葬管理條例》以人為主，寵物不在規範的範圍；而《動物保護法》僅規範動物生前對待，對動物死亡後處置，未有任何規範。直到經濟部商業司於2023年1月增列「寵物生命紀念業」營業項目；農業部自2023年7月，訂定「非都市土地申請變更為寵物生命紀念設施使用興辦事業計畫審查作業要點」，寵物殯葬業者才有法可遵循。然而制度推行兩年多，全國僅核准19間業者完成合法程序，與現況落差甚大。
▲當事鼠暖暖，三年前於新北市八里區僅火化寵物鼠要價5千元，寵物鼠重量500g收費卻同等5公斤貓狗的標準。（圖／讀者提供）
有民眾向《三立新聞網》分享，過去飼養的小白鼠「暖暖」在2021年離世，悲痛萬分的他希望能陪著小白鼠走完最後一哩路，因此找來寵物殯葬業進行火化，豈料「燒成骨灰就被收了5000元，寵物鼠重量500g收費卻同等5公斤貓狗的標準」，昂貴價格讓他無法置信。
▲張姓民眾寵物鼠過世後進行火化，被殯葬業者收費4500元。（圖／讀者提供）
另一位同樣飼養寵物鼠的張姓民眾也控訴，2019年陪伴他多年的寵物鼠過世後，與女友聯繫寵物殯葬業，當時對方報價4500元，內容包括載運飼主與家屬來回火化區、火化寵物鼠以及骨灰罈，張姓民眾透露，骨灰罈的大小約莫小罐的鋁箔啤酒罐，「雖然覺得收費不合理，但還能怎麼辦？」
▲張姓民眾分享，寵物鼠過世後被裝入骨灰罈，大小大約小罐的鋁箔啤酒罐。（圖／讀者提供）
面對寵物殯葬坐地起價亂象，立委李坤城今（29）邀集郭昱晴委員及農業部動物保護司副司長陳中興、行政院消費者保護處簡任秘書呂惠珍，以及行政院法規會參議吳怡芳與環境部循環署副組長梁開忠等主管機關，共同召開「落實監督管理 杜絕寵物殯葬亂象叢生」記者會。
▲李坤城及郭昱晴要求農業部盡速提出定型化契約草案，並且盡快整合地方政府將審查回歸地方與設置合法業者查詢平台。（圖／記者李育道攝影）
李坤城及郭昱晴要求農業部盡速提出定型化契約草案，並且盡快整合地方政府將審查回歸地方與設置合法業者查詢平台，讓毛小孩或其他寵物的生命最後旅程中，都值得被好好送別，飼主也應該有安心告別的權利，期待政府協助打造一個安全、合法、透明。
▲陳中興允諾，會於六月底前，研擬定型化契約草案，保護消費者有公開透明的收費標準。（圖／記者李育道攝影）
對此，農業部動保局陳中興副司長則允諾，會於六月底前，研擬定型化契約草案，保護消費者有公開透明的收費標準，同時正在研議簡化申請流程，將審查機制整併至地方政府，未來不用再做兩段式審查，其次將合法業者公布於農業部動物保護資訊平台，讓飼主可以安心的讓寵物走得莊嚴、走得體面。

author: Scripps News
title: Protesters attempt to block aid into Gaza, demand release of hostages
text: Protesters attempt to block aid into Gaza, demand release of hostages Protesters in Israel are attempting to prevent humanitarian aid from entering into Gaza as they demand the immediate release of the more than 100 hostages that have been held captive by Hamas since the Oct. 7 terrorist attack on Israel.Dozens of demonstrators gathered Wednesday at Israel's Ashdod Port in attempt to block trucks from transporting goods and supplies for Palestinians into the Gaza Strip. Footage from the scene showed protesters harassing truck drivers, while others held signs that read "no aid for terrorists."As part of a temporary cease-fire in November, Israel agreed to allow up to 200 trucks a day to transport aid and goods into Gaza in exchange for the release of 105 hostages held by Hamas. However, protests have erupted over the past week demanding that additional aid be withheld until all remaining hostages are set free.SEE MORE: Here's where things stand on a potential Israel-Hamas hostage dealThis comes as a coalition of negotiators from the United States and Middle Eastern countries is working to secure a temporary truce that would allow for more hostages to be released. In exchange, Israel would pull back military operation in Gaza for six weeks, while also releasing three Palestinian prisoners for every Israeli hostage set free. Senior Hamas officials met with Egyptian negotiators in Cairo Wednesday to discuss the details of the proposal specifically the timeline in which it could play out. Israeli officials have reportedly accepted parts of the proposal, in principle, but Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has repeatedly vowed to continue war efforts until Israel achieves "total victory" over Hamas.With up to 80% of the Palestinian population in Gaza now displaced, the war is quickly becoming one of the world's worst humanitarian disasters. According to the United Nations, Israel's offensive in the region has forced as many as 1.8 million Palestinians to flee their homes. But overcrowded shelters, combined with the loss of basic health and sanitation necessities, is causing dire humanitarian concerns. Latest video
